article.title: Ehrlichia chaffeensis replication sites in adult Drosophila melanogaster
funding: Kansas Agriculture Experiment Station Animal Health Project grant 481848
Terry C. Johnson Center for Basic Cancer Research
article.abstract: Ehrlichia chaffeensis is a Gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium which causes the tick-borne disease human monocytic ehrlichiosis. In vertebrates, E. chaffeensis replicates in monocytes and macrophages. However, no clear cell or tissue tropism has been defined in arthropods.

sections.introduction: Human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME) is a tick-borne, zoonotic disease caused by the Gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium, Ehrlichia chaffeensis.
sections.methods: E. chaffeensis (Arkansas isolate) was propagated in DH82 cells (American Type Culture collection, #CRL-10389, Rockville, Md.).
sections.results: E. chaffeensis is capable of infecting and completing its life cycle in Drosophila S2 cells and adult flies.
sections.discussion: Our data confirm that Uck2 and san are needed for E. chaffeensis replication (Von Ohlen et al., 2012) and support the hypothesis that the bacteria replicate in the hemocytes or the fat body in adult D. melanogaster.

article.insights_summary: Ehrlichia chaffeensis replicates in the hemocytes and fat body of adult Drosophila melanogaster.
